item.title: One the passing of my father
item.description:
On Tuesday, I got word from my half-sister that my father has passed away. I believe he was 85 years old. This has led to some rather complex emotions over the passed couple of days.

For a little background, my parents divorsed when I was young. I'm not sure exactly how old I was because my childhood memories are extremely fuzzy, plus my perception of time seems scewed to begin with, but I would guess around five years old. I say this because I have a vague recollection of starting school in one school and my mom walking me to that school. Then I remember transferring to another school in kindergarden, and I remember the house we lived in when I went to the second one, and we lived there with my dad and step-mother (my dad's third wife, as I recall). So obviously my father got custody of my sisters (one younger, one older) and I.

When I was 8, we moved to Florida. After a year and a half or so, my older sister decided she wanted to go live with our mom and step-dad. Our father agreed to let her and my sister go live there, since he didn't want to separate the two. But at 9, he gave me the choice to stay with him or go with my sisters. For the longest time, I hated him for making me choose my sisters over him, but obviously did.

I only saw or spoke to him once after that, and it was when I was a teen and still bitter about it. I have long since let that hatred, anger, and bitterness go, and replaced them with... nothing...

For his part, I don't know much about what happened after my sisters and I left. I know he remarried his fourh wife, and he had three more children with her. Two more girls and a boy. That marraige lasted until her passing a year or two ago.

For my part, I realize that he was probably afraid that I'd have felt pushed away, so thought he was sparing me that by giving me a choice. I suspect he already knew the outcome, or didn't plan on separate us and would have talked me into going with me sisters.

Because I knew he was getting up there in age, and I'm in my 50s and becoming more and more aware of my own mortality, I'd recently started thinging about getting in touch, if just to let him know I didn't hold any annimosity. I've also thought about getting ahold of my half-siblings, whom I've never met, to see if they would help me know him through their eyes. I don't remember much about my father, and it is tainted by all those years of resentment.

His passing has triggered some very vague and fuzzy memories, though, and I can only speculate on what I remember correctly, and what my mind is filling in.

For instance, I have a very fuzzy memory if it being nighttime, us being outside at our grandparents' home, and flashing lights, someone holding a baby on the porch (either my mom or grandma holding my little sister, most likely), and my dad standing with his hands behind his back like a soldier standing at- ease. I seem to remember someone screaming at my father, probably my mother, and maybe police? The flashing lights were maybe from their cars? Maybe my dad was getting arrested for a domestic situation?

I also think maybe the divorce was a result of my mom cheating on him. It was the 70's, and courts usually favored the mother when it came to custody, of all my friends growing up who had divorced parents, very few of their fathers had even split custody. So the only way my father would have gotten custody is if my mother just okay, or if she had caused the end of the marraige.

This is just speculation, of course, but now there is no one who could verify any of it. My older sister passed away over nine years ago, and we never really talked about our father. My little sisted was just a baby, and had cut tied with the family regardless. I doubt my half-siblings would have heard much about his previous life.

item.title: NAS
item.description:
For quite some time, I have beeing building servers out of outdated computers to use as network-attached storage but throwing as much storage into it as I can afford at the time. I've currently got a moderately powerful early-generation i7 with 3 8TB drives in it (plus a separate 2TB boot and applications drive) running everything, but it is not very power-efficient, being probably a decade old or more at this point. So, I finally ordered my first proper NAS because if there's a chance I'll be living out of the RV at some point, I would like something a bit more power-friendly since I only have 30-amp service there. I plan to upgrade that at some point, and also go solar, but limiting my power requirements probably isn't a bad idea in general.

item.title: Scaremail
item.description:
It's not quite an ARG, but it has many elements of one. Horror author David Viergutz has created a very ARG-like experience delivered as two letters per month for a year, which I bought for my wife some time back. I decided I wanted my own copy, so I ordered it for myself as well about a month later, putting me two letters behind her in the experience. There are websites to visit, phone numbers to call, etc., though I don't believe they will have much impact on the story other than making it feel more interactive. I'm currently eight letters in, out of twenty-four, and it is starting to get a bit creepy. The story is told as letters back and forth between a reader and David, with several other artifacts being included along the way. I've been enjoying it so much that I've been thinking CiW could use the same type of treatment, and if I could get more than an introductory letter, I'd probably launch something similar. ;)

Tags: arg, scaremail, scare.me

item.title: lg15.com
item.description:
The official lg15.com has been down for a few weeks now, and I have contacted Miles about it. While he responded when I first noticed it by saying he would check into it and asking if I wanted to help maintain it, he has not responded to any further inquiries. I do not know where it stands, but it appears that the web server has been shut down for some reason. It should be a matter of the hosting company starting it back up, and then the official site is back.

That said, I am not one to wait around. ;) Since I have a bunch of the databases from when I previously helped to restore lgpedia, I set up an unofficial mirror at lg15.cassieiswatching.com. I couldn't get the old version of phpBB2 to work properly, so I upgraded the forums to phpBB3. There's a quirk with the "last post" author and date, but otherwise all the old posts from 2007-ish are still there. For lgpedia, I just linked to an existing fan mirror of it.

I built this on top of a couple old projects I had written for Cassie Watchers. The first one was a search for the forums. The second was another search, this time for the comments from the old Wordpress version of the site. And finally, I had put together a list of all the videos as a list of the old posts along with their comments.

Tags: lonelygirl15, lg15, cassieiswatching, ciw

item.title: Cross Country 2024
item.description:
I intended to do updates of my daughter's Cross Country running times, but time got away from me. Instead, here's summary of her 2024 season:

Her first 1 mile race that I posed about was on 8/24, and she finished in 10:27.

During her following practice on 8/26, she ran a 14:36 mile. The slower time is probably due to the hotter weather, the practice course being a bit rougher, and she had just competed in her first race and didn't have any recocery time.

She ran a 12:31 mile on 8/31.

On 9/6, she had her first 2K race and finished in 13:54.

On 9/17, she broke a 10 minute mile with a time of 9:52.

Three days later, she ran another 2K and finished in 13:08.

Her last race of the season was her longest yet, a 3K which she finished in 20:06.

To cap off her season, there was one last timed mile at practice the following Monday, which she finished in 9:19, which was over five minutes faster than her first practice timed run and a over a minute faster than her first race.

I am so proud of this girl's accomplishments this season, setting a new personal best almost every time she ran during her very first season of cross country.

Tags: running, cross-country

item.title: Comments Enabled
item.description:
I don't like running a blog where I cannot interact with users, so comments are now enabled via Disqus.
